inputs.text: Walk me through what you mean by homeless octopus.

Okay, so imagine you're house-hunting, but your entire survival depends on finding the perfect spot. Cosmos would approach a crevice - always leading with his left front arm, by the way - and just... investigate. Testing the walls, measuring the space, checking the angles to the current, mapping out potential escape routes.
Wait, he's thinking about escape routes while house hunting?
Always. These are prey animals living in a world full of sharks. Every home needs to be a fortress. And I watched him reject spot after spot. Too exposed. Too shallow. Wrong angle. He had standards.

That's the thing that kept hitting me. Here's a creature whose last common ancestor with us was some simple worm-like thing half a billion years ago. And he's house-hunting with the same criteria I'd use: safety, accessibility, good sightlines, multiple exits.
So when did he find his perfect place?
Day eight. And Mark, when he found it, you could see it in his body language. His chromatophores - those color-changing cells - shifted to calmer tones. His movements slowed. He'd found it.
